Award.AwardTitle: Software Engineering Master's Program for Liberal Arts Graduates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project plans to increase the number of highly skilled and talented software engineers in the workplace through scholarships. Stevens Institute of Technology proposes an 18-month Software Engineering (SwE) Master's Degree program to accomplish this in conjunction with offering 35 S-STEM scholarships over a 4 year period. The master's program will consist of 10 required courses, two electives, a summer bridge program, and a recommended summer internship. The program will build upon Stevens' nationally ranked career center and strong connections with local industry. Graduates will be well-qualified to enter the STEM workforce as software developers, testers, architects, and requirements engineers.

Recruitment of scholarship applicants will focus on students from liberal arts colleges. These students are often of very high ability, but find themselves under or un-employed with substantial student debt. Liberal Arts graduates have a higher percentage of women so that this program should improve the diversity of the STEM workforce. Recruitment efforts will include information sessions, mini-courses, and direct advertising to students and alumni. No formal computing background will be assumed, but students are expected to have strong quantitative skills. Evaluation data will be collected during recruitment, while students are applying, and while they are in the program. The collected recruitment data will focus upon the mini-courses and will be used to refine the courses. The application data will be collected by the Stevens' Graduate Admissions Office for both accepted and rejected students and will include applicant demographics, educational background, exposure to recruitment efforts, and admission decision. Extensive survey data will be collected during the two years students are in the program. The success of the entire program will be evaluated in recruitment, in retention, and in successfully placing students in long-term careers in software engineering. Results will be disseminated through conference presentations and journals and there are plans for a workshop to teach faculty members from other schools how to replicate the program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was established in 2014 to provide scholarship dollars to students recruited from undergraduate liberal arts majors for graduate study leading to an MS in software engineering.  These students were provided with mentoring and academic support as needed to insure they become accomplished in the STEM disciple of software engineering. 

Initially, 3 annual cohorts of 10-15 liberal arts graduates were envisioned, with ramp coursework as needed to introduce computing and software fundamentals and subsequent standard coursework leading to the master?s degree. Cohort support and mentoring by faculty was to be provided. From the onset, however, the project was unable to attract students. Students without significant computing background were either not interested in pursuing a software engineering degree or were more attracted to the ?code academies? that formed during the mid-teens offering free, no-cost, or delayed cost programs in coding with job placement.

Over the life of the project, we attracted only six students: three women and three men. All six were successful in achieving their Master of Science degree in Software Engineering and all have found employment in the software industry. With so few students, less than $75,000 of the original grant was distributed in scholarships. No other funds were disbursed.

The underlying hypothesis for this program, that appropriate instruction would allow talented liberal arts graduates to succeed as master's level software engineers was supported by the program's results; however with so few students, the applicability of the hypothesis to larger populations was not demonstrated. 

The program encouraged the software engineering faculty at the Stevens Institute of Technology to think ?outside the box? in how they taught their subject. Two papers looking at a novel approach to estimating effort in software development were written and presented at conferences on software engineering education and training. A new graduate-level course in software development tools was developed, initially as a ramp course for this program?s students but quickly embraced as a critically important component for all software engineering graduate students. It continues to be a highly recommended first term course for software engineering graduate students at Stevens Institute of Technology.
